holdings.text: The first limit to the jurisdiction of the High Court as laid down by this Court is thus not exceeded by the High Court in exercising its powers under s. 66(4) of the Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: The first limit to the jurisdiction of the High Court as laid down by this Court is thus number exceeded by the High Court in exercising its powers under s. 66 4  of the Income-tax Act. The question is wide enough

holdings.reasoning_summary: Referred question is wide ('Whether on the facts and circumstances of the case the profits and gains [...] were received by the assessee in taxable territories?') allowing inquiry into request for postal remittance, unlike narrow question in Jehangir Vakil Mills.

holdings.text: The question is wide enough to include the alternative line of approach that if there was a request, express or implied, to send the amount due under the bills by cheque, the post office would be the agent of the assessee, and the income was received in the taxable territory when the cheques were posted.

anchor.surface_text: The question is wide enough to include the alternative line of approach that if there was a request, express or implied, to sent the amount due under the bills by cheque, the post office would be the agent of the assessee, and the income was received in the taxable territory

holdings.reasoning_summary: Comparison of referred questions shows current one broad enough to encompass post office agency per Ogale Glass Works and Jagdish Mills precedents.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court order interpreted charitably as limited to existing record, avoiding fresh evidence prohibited by Jehangir Vakil Mills.

holdings.text: The case thus set two limits to the jurisdiction of the High Court under s. 66(4), and they were that the advisory jurisdiction was confined (a) to the facts on the record and or found by the Tribunal and (b) the question which would arise from the Tribunals order.

precedents.citation: Sir Sobha Singh v. Commissioner of Income-tax  1950 18 I.T.R. 998

anchor.surface_text: Sir Sobha Singh v. Commissioner of Income-tax  1950 18 I.T.R. 998 , it was held by the Punjab High Court that where cheques were given to a bank for purposes of companylection, the receipt of the money was at the place where the bank on which the cheque was drawn was situated. These views found further amplification, were applied in two other cases by the Bombay High Court.

precedents.cited_proposition: Receipt of money by cheque collection at place where drawee bank situated

precedents.cited_proposition: Mere posting of cheque not receipt unless express request to send by post

precedents.citation: Ogale Glass Works Ltd, v. Commissioner of Income-tax  I. Tax Reference No. 19 of 1949 of Bombay H.C. decided on September 17 1951

anchor.surface_text: Ogale Glass Works Ltd, v. Commissioner of Income-tax  I. Tax Reference No. 19 of 1949 of Bombay H.C. decided on September 17 1951 . In both these cases, it was held that unless the payee expressly companystituted the post office as his agent, the mere posting of the cheque did number companystitute the post office the agent of the payee, and that the amount of the cheque was also received at the place where the cheque was received.

precedents.case_name: Ogale Glass Works Ltd v Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents.cited_proposition: No agency of post office without express request; receipt where cheque received

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Ogale Class Works Ltd. and Commissioner of Income-tax v. Kirloskar Bros. Ltd.  1954 25 I.T.R. 547

It was held that where the bills had an endorsement Government should pay the amount due by cheque and the cheques were received in full satisfaction unconditionally, this companystituted a sufficient implied request for the purpose of the application of the rule in Ogale Glass Works case of this Court.
